fields.description:
Currently Bamboo shows the same rotating circle icon for build plans triggered for build but waiting agent in queue and for build plans that are in real progress.
It might be useful to have a different icon and probably a short status string that clearly show the difference.
fields.summary: Different icons in build overview for build plans that are running and build plans that are queued

fields.description:
Logging in Bamboo (with Crowd integrated) throws a null pointer exception as we are using crowd-integration-client-1.3.jar file.

Note, this only occurs if the customer is using [this ehcache.xml file|http://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/198785/crowd-ehcache.xml?version=1] - which is meant to be the workaround for CWD-1167

Reported in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-1197
fields.summary: Upgrade Bamboo's crowd-client library

fields.description: The Current activity tab shows all the builds that are currently building/queued - it would be helpful if it also showed what/who triggered the build.
fields.summary: The current activity tab should show how the build was triggered

fields.description: We need Bamboo to have the option for build history to be retained (for ever) even after the build has expired and build information and artifacts are deleted.  This allows for historical statistics to be retained log after the need for the build information
fields.summary: Option to delete build results but keep build history

fields.description:
We have scheduled builds at 4 AM, however, they occasionally die without explanation.  Upon closer review the sync from perforce is timing out.  Perforce is very responsive, and has no issues from anywhere else, including on the build machine either through the gui or command line...

One thing of note is that in the agent, the console window is being spammed with perforce sync messages.  This is probably a bad idea.  This sync data is probably better handles being written out to a log file.
fields.summary: Perforce Syncs are timing out

fields.description:
For example, the build strategy and polling frequency or trigger IP address are something you might want to configure once for a given Subversion server. Our svn server's IP address changed, and having to go into lots of plugin projects individually on bamboo.developer.atlassian.com to change the trigger IP was rather tedious and potentially error-prone (did I miss any? who knows?)

Even better would be defaults for a given repository that could be optionally overridden per-project.
fields.summary: Some Source Repository configuration should be associated with the respository server instead of each project

fields.description:
The concept of triggering a build using a Subversion (or other scm) commit hook is a good one, but from a build plan maintenance standpoint it's not realistic to update the svn commit hook every time a build plan is added, removed, or has its keys changed.  So the triggering implementation [documented here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/3.2.2+Triggering+a+Build+on+Code+Check-in] isn't workable, so we rely on polling and the checkout process is much less efficient than it could be.

At my company, editing the commit hook requires working with operations; adding/editing a build plan is something an engineer can do.

It seems the proper way to create a build trigger would be to have the post-commit hook call Bamboo on every commit (or potentially some subset of all commits - that can be scripted).  Then Bamboo does a quick check (using {{svn log}}) and maps the paths of all the modified files to the build plans in Bamboo using each file's svn path.  This creates a candidate list of build plans to trigger as a result of the commit.  Of the candidate list, only the build plans that are set to "trigger build when scm changes" would be triggered.
fields.summary: Multiplex Bamboo builds from a subversion commit trigger based on build plan svn path

fields.description:
When I unpack the tar.gz distribution, it dumps everything in a directory called {{Bamboo/}}.  This breaks the widely followed convention of having a top-level directory that a) is lowercase, b) includes the version, eg. {{bamboo-2.1.1/}}. Omitting the version means that if I untar into {{/usr/local}}, I will clobber and corrupt my existing Bamboo installation. Having random uppercase letters just breaks alphabetic listings.

By all means keep {{Bamboo}} for the .dmg distribution, but please follow the conventions of what users expect a tar.gz to contain, like all other Atlassian product tar.gz's do.
fields.summary: Top-level directory should include version, be lowercased

fields.summary: Freemarker exception in the logs while paginating the JIRA issues for a build.

fields.description:
The [Agent install doc| http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+Remote+Agent+Installation+Guide] is misleading as it suggest to start the *remote* agent with _localhost_ as parameter.  starting the *remote* agent (java -jar ....) will NEVER be localhost - because it's a *remote* AGENT - the host (bamboo server) is most probably on a different ip address.
The documentation and screenshots need to be corrected. They should not mention localhost at all.
fields.summary: The Agent installation documentation is ambiguous

fields.description:
We check whether or not the build was run on the agent _after_ we try and retrieve the source code directory.  Perforce throws an error if it can't find the directory (because it only exists on the remote agent) which is being passed to the user rather than the appropriate 'nice' error message.

{quote}We are using Perforce and most of our plans are built on remote agents using Perforce clients which can be used only the agent's machine with the workspace not being managed by Bamboo. Whenever we try to display a plan's working files we get the error message 'An unexpected error has occurred' and the following is written in the server's log file

INFO [http-8080-1] [CmdLineExecutor] Executing: c:/programs/Perforce/p4.exe clients
INFO [http-8080-1] [CmdLineExecutor] Executing: c:/programs/Perforce/p4.exe client -o bamboo_07h122913_GenericPackage1.0_GenericPackage
ERROR [http-8080-1] [ViewBuildFiles] Failed to calculate build file directory
com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Unable to extract client root from Perforce, therefore could not evaluate where the source will be checked out to.
at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.perforce.PerforceManager.getClientRoot(PerforceManager.java:172)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.perforce.PerforceRepository.getSourceCodeDirectory(PerforceRepository.java:638)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.ViewBuildFiles.doExecute(ViewBuildFiles.java:53)

When you execute the command 'p4.exe client -o ...' on a command line, however, the root directory is printed correctly. This directory does not exist on the server, but only on the agent machine.
{quote}

fields.summary: Remote agent crashes with java exception

fields.description: When creating or updating a build plan, Bamboo auto-executes the build plan, which in a lot of cases is exactly the behavior that I don't want.  Build plans should execute ONLY when I tell them to, or when their scheduled time arrives, never because the app thinks it should.
fields.summary: Remove "build auto-execution" feature

fields.description:
I would like one or more methods to help document and understand how the build plans change over time.  A change to a build plan can have major ramifications to the result produced by the build so it is important to understand and document changes to the plan.  For example, our prior build processes, the build process was controlled by scripts that were themselves in source control and therefore had a version history.  There are various levels of support that would help in this regard:
# Add a comment field when a plan configuration is saved so that change can be documented
# Provide automatic versioning of plans (like Confluence page versioning for instance) where differences between versions could be highlighted
# Provide a text representation of the plan that can be imported/exported to source control
#* Perhaps even a configuration so that plan changes are automatically put into source control
# Optionally require a JIRA issue to be associated with any plan change
fields.summary: Plan configuration change control and versioning

fields.description:
From [BSP-1168|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-1168] -
{quote}
Please add the following lines to the Bamboo startup script for Unix (the bamboo.sh bash script):

if [ -f /etc/sysconfig/bamboo ]; then
  . /etc/sysconfig/bamboo
fi

That will allow us to add environment customizations, eg. setting environment variables, to the /etc/sysconfig/bamboo file.

Thanks!{quote}
fields.summary: Add a directive to allow users to configure system variables in Bamboo

fields.description:
See these skitches:

* http://skitch.com/farkas/w8sf/local-agent-proc2-opensource-bamboo
* http://skitch.com/farkas/w8se/local-agent-proc2-opensource-bamboo

I raised this as a bug, as the 3rd Skitch shows a permissions problem.  If you can fix the others while you are there, that would be great.
fields.summary: UI Improvements to local agents page

fields.description:
When Crowd is configured not to let Bamboo manage users and groups, Bamboo still offers the possibility to create new groups. And if groups are being created in this way Bamboo will fail with an internal server error.

First off all if the service is disabled in Crowd then Bamboo should not offer the possibility to change groups. Second, if there is an attempt to create groups, a permission denied error would be more appropriate than a internet server error.
fields.summary: Bamboo shouldn't try to add users in Crowd, when it doesn't have directory rights to add principals

fields.description: From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-1157 - Bamboo sends out false notification as the logic for getFixesBuild() for the  AfterXFailedBuilds condition is flawed.
fields.summary: Bamboo sends out false notifications, if the build has failed after X builds

fields.description:
If a remote agent is behind a firewall (relative to the Bamboo server), one of the connections from the server to the remote agent may be closed by the firewall after a timeout, preventing the remote agent from receiving builds.

The heartbeat mechanism continues to operate, however, so the agent still appears to be online.
fields.summary: Some builds assigned to a remote agent behind a firewall are never built

fields.description: The artifact redirect for latest artifacts only apply to top the top level artifact directory, i.e. http://<Bamboo>/download/PLAN_KEY/artifacts/LATEST/<Artifact_Name> and you can't reference specific artifacts within the root <artifact_Name> directory, i.e http://<Bamboo>/download/PLAN_KEY/artifacts/LATEST/<Artifact_Name>/my_fancy_file.txt
fields.summary: The LATEST URL redirect(s) only apply to top level artifacts.

fields.description:
If we are going to officially support weblogic -
* Fix up the agent issue.
* We need to start running integration tests against weblogic
* We also need to decide on what version(s) of weblogic we are going to support.
fields.summary: Remote classloading fails on Weblogic 9.1 and 9.2
Add the agent information of the agent executing the build to the Build Context.

fields.description:
If there are more than 1 agents capable of building a plan (the plan has built once before on the agents) and the Source repository URL on the plan changes.

The change is only picked up by the *first* agent that builds the plan after the Repository URL changes, we need to perform a *clean* build on all the other agents that hold reference to the old Repository URL.
fields.summary: SVN URL change is not picked up by all the agent.

fields.description:
It seems that the perforce client will not time out requests to the server.  So if, for some reason, there is no response the client just sits there.  This means that bamboo also just sits there, tying up the threads that could be used for building other things.  This is particularly evident when the client and server are a long way apart.   

Bamboo needs to have a timeout (preferably configurable) as to how long it waits for the command to return something.
fields.summary: Perforce calls never time out

fields.description:
It appears from looking at log files that each individual file in an artifact collection is transmitted as a single JMS message. This isn't particularly great for a lot of our plans, where we copy over a hierarchy of JUnit HTML and Clover HTML reports. They can take many minutes to copy the artifacts (where artifact copying takes far longer than the actual build itself).

Would it be possible to batch up artifact copying in some way to reduce the length of time it takes to copy large numbers of small files?
fields.summary: Artifact collections with large numbers of small files take forever to copy
Can't assign LDAP users against local Bamboo groups.

fields.description:
We gave a trigger reason applied to a build context, so if plan B is a child build of Plan A - plan B knows why it was triggered.

However, incase of multiple dependent builds (Plan A -> Plan B -> Plan C) - the Plan C knows that its a dependent build of Plan B, but Plan C doesn't realize/know that it was kicked off due to a code commit in Plan A.
fields.summary: The Trigger reason from a parent build is not passed down to a linked child dependent build.

fields.description:
Our currnent implementation relied on SVNKit throwning an exception when a repository is locked

However, it turns out that - SVNKit doesn't throw exception when one of external locations is locked, instead it skips it and proceeds with the next external.
fields.summary: Locks on svn:externals repository should be detected and cleaned

fields.description:
Show on build info screen what builds will be triggered if the build is successful.

This is useful information to put on this screen. To get this info currently, you need to go to the Config->Dependencies tab. Showing if the dependent plans previously failed or passed (by red or green color) would be also excellent.
fields.summary: Show on build info screen what builds will be triggered if the build is successful
If perforce files end up open for edit, syncs dont work but Bamboo still builds

fields.description:
Upgrading Bamboo deletes all LDAP settings

The OSX installer deletes the entire Bamboo installation, including all previously configured LDAP config. Since it took me about 4 hours to get that working last time due to crappy LDAP documentation for Bamboo, I am not looking forward to doing this again.
fields.summary: Installer wipes previous install location which can cause loss of config data

fields.description:
Add plugin point so that Agent/Build matching can be customised when either adding or rebuilding the build queue.

This is useful for implementing "exclusive" matching where you may want to only run on a particular agent where a certained capability and requirement equal each other.
fields.summary: Add plugin point so that Agent/Build matching can be customised

fields.description:
Bamboo indexes a lot of data. In a high use installation, it's not uncommon for the indexes to be 10GB. While reindexing shouldn't really need to occur, we should look at ways to trim down the index and not lose the core functionality.

For reference an instance with 13 million builds + tests (documents) takes ~ 6GB of optimised index size.
fields.summary: Index takes up a lot of disk space

fields.description:
Currently the are 2 roles for notification - watchers and commiters.

There should be a third role for the person that triggered the build. In case of a manual build there is no way to notify the user that kicked off the build, of build outcome.
fields.summary: Add notification rule to notify the person who triggered a manual build.

fields.description:
I understand the low-hanging fruit of the JUnit test results format.  Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to be documented.  It's also lacking as a format and Bamboo's interpretation of it is occasionally surprising (see BAM-2627 )

I would love to have one of:
- API for interacting with test results
- Formal documentation of test result format
- Better test result format, formally documented

If you aren't using JUnit, Bamboo's ability to deal with tests is greatly reduced.
fields.summary: Provide an API for interacting with test results, or formally document the results file format

fields.description: There should be a way of editing existing artifact definitions and setting the order that the artifacts appear.  In our build environment, we have several plans with dozens of artifacts and locating and the inability to edit existing artifact entries  (for misspellings, path differences, etc) makes administration cumbersome.  Also, since there is no way to choose the order of the artifacts, it is difficult for users to locate the specific artifacts they are looking for.
fields.summary: Improve artifact editing

fields.description:
Make perforce polling more efficient, to reduce CPU usage.

Currently we need to make 3-4 calls to the perforce server every time we poll it for changes.  These calls are relatively CPU intensive (text parsing).  We need to look at finding a way to either reduce the number of calls required or to make them a bit more efficient.

One idea is to let the user input information that we regularly retrieve for example the client root or the left hand side of the depot mapping to allow the user to make the decision between maintainability (harder to keep bamboo and perforce in sync) and performance.
fields.summary: Perforce polling uses up too much CPU

fields.description:
The default values for the JIRA issue cache (24 hours) and the JIRA metadata cache (~10 days) are far too long, and will result in unacceptably stale data appearing in the Bamboo UI.

The JIRA metadata cache always updates stale data on a background thread, and uses stale data rather than blocking user requests, so its expiry period can and should be set much lower (1 minute?).

Once the JIRA issue cache has been modified to behave in the same way, and to cache the non-existence of an issue, it should also have its expiry period lowered (again, 1 minute would be appropriate).
fields.summary: JIRA issue cache should update in background, and expiry periods should be shortened

fields.description:
On BEAC, my details were displayed correctly until I edited my profile information, at which point all my details no longer appear in Bamboo.

https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/profile/editProfile.action

This seems to be the same problem as BAM-1713 and BAM-1681, except for:

- it's happening in Bamboo 2.0.6
- it's happening on our server, that is presumably configured correctly. (The resolution for BAM-1681 was a configuration error.)

Please advise how to fix this.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

We have a setup with a central build server and multiple remote agents on similar Linux servers.
 We have a set of environment variables we need to exist when every build is run - currently:
{noformat}
ANT_OPTS="-XX:MaxPermSize=256m -Xmx1024m -Djava.awt.headless=true"
HOSTNAME=`/bin/hostname`
hostname=`/bin/hostname`
{noformat}
Bamboo is started by an init script, as are the remote agents, which we've deployed using the Tanuki Java Service Wrapper.
 To get all our plans to build with these environment variables we either have to maintain them for each plan (we will have 100+ of these when we've rolled out fully) or use OS level fu to manage them.
 Currently we're doing the latter, which involves:
 * Editing {{/etc/profile}} (or another appropriate file) on the servers to declare these environment variables
 * Editing the Tanuki wrapper script on the server and each remote agent to include these variables when it runs (otherwise they're lost when the service is restarted via sudo)

What we'd like to do is be able to manage these environment variables at a server (and potentially project) level to set defaults.
 These would be provided to each local and remote agent when they launched the builder for a plan, but could be overridden by settings in plans.

Some of these environment variables are associated with builders (e.g. ANT_HOME), so it might be that there's also the ability to configure environment variables for builders as well as globally. This would actually give us the ability to isolate scarier variables to specific builds that needed them.
h3. Suggested Solution

Implement environment variable management from Bamboo host to Remote agents
h3. Workaround

You can add Environment Variables to Agents in {{<bamboo-agent-home>/conf/wrapper.conf}} using the format *set.VARIABLE_NAME=variable_value*.

For example, the following can be added to {{wrapper.conf}} on your agent(s):
{noformat}
#********************************************************************
# Environment Variables
#********************************************************************
# These variables will be used by the Bamboo agent
# All will start with "set" -- Format:
# set.KEY=value
set.VARIABLE1=value1
set.VARIABLE2=value2{noformat}
See [Tanuki Software Java Service Wrapper - Environment Variable Definition|https://wrapper.tanukisoftware.com/doc/english/props-envvars.html#definition] for more information
fields.summary: Environment variables for agents
